COL.DATA: According to the archeologists, this first phase, called Horizon 1, begun in late 9th century and lasted up to beginnings of 10th century, The building consisted of a simple geometric plan with one rectangular nave and one apse at the east end. One main door opened at the west wall. No painted decoration associated
2. Segona fase, c. mitjan segle X - començament segle XI (figs. 6-9, 18-19, 33-40, 68, 70, 74-76). Horitzons II i III.
The building material was rubble masonry joined with lime mortar.

Early Medieval Phase I: trapezial shape in plan with straight east wall. A horseshoe-shape vault covered the room. One window was opened right on the middle of the east wall. The second window is more debated, but it existed since de first construction of the building. The apse plan and vault never changed although the many events and modifications suffered by the building.
Same as nowadays, but it seems that the vault was less tall.
1 window opened at the middle of the East wall 1 window opened at the South wall.
Trapezial plan covered with horseshoe shaped vault
At the beginning of the 12th century, a more ambitious campaign of Romanesque-style frescoes adorned the eastern third of the church, covering the earlier decoration.
Interior church - central apse and nave - 1st Restoration

Fundació Institut Amatller d'Art Hispànic, Arxiu Mas
Central nave lost painting - north wall

Crist crucified type "Majestat". Remains of the lower layer of paintings in the nave, discovered by J. Gudiol in 1937.
Gudiol informed that a Romanesque version of the Christ crucified, right above the first one, was discovered, but there are no images of this second figure.

At the beginning of the 12th century, a more ambitious campaign of Romanesque-style frescoes adorned the eastern third of the church, covering the earlier decoration.

According to the archeologists, this first phase, called Horizon 1, begun in late 9th century and lasted up to beginnings of 10th century, The building consisted of a simple geometric plan with one rectangular nave and one apse at the east end. One main door opened at the west wall. No painted decoration associated
2. Segona fase, c. mitjan segle X - començament segle XI (figs. 6-9, 18-19, 33-40, 68, 70, 74-76). Horitzons II i III.
The building material was rubble masonry joined with lime mortar.

Early Medieval Phase I: trapezial shape in plan with straight east wall. A horseshoe-shape vault covered the room. One window was opened right on the middle of the east wall. The second window is more debated, but it existed since de first construction of the building. The apse plan and vault never changed although the many events and modifications suffered by the building.
Same as nowadays, but it seems that the vault was less tall.
1 window opened at the middle of the East wall 1 window opened at the South wall.

2. Segona fase, c. mitjan segle X - començament segle XI (figs. 6-9, 18-19, 33-40, 68, 70, 74-76). Horitzons II i III.
The building material was rubble masonry joined with lime mortar.

Early Medieval Phase I: trapezial shape in plan with straight east wall. A horseshoe-shape vault covered the room. One window was opened right on the middle of the east wall. The second window is more debated, but it existed since de first construction of the building. The apse plan and vault never changed although the many events and modifications suffered by the building.
Same as nowadays, but it seems that the vault was less tall.
1 window opened at the middle of the East wall 1 window opened at the South wall.
Trapezial plan covered with horseshoe shaped vault
At the beginning of the 12th century, a more ambitious campaign of Romanesque-style frescoes adorned the eastern third of the church, covering the earlier decoration.
